titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Buildings, Grounds and Landmarks in New Haven Photographs
Buildings, Grounds and Landmarks in New Haven Photographs
titlestmt.author: compiled by Manuscripts and Archives Staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Friday January 4, 2019 at 08:09

did.unittitle: Buildings, grounds and landmarks in New Haven photographs

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The materials consist of maps, photographs, engravings, drawings, slides, and lithographs of New Haven, Connecticut scenes, residences, buildings, and landmarks. The bulk of The materials consist of photographs of New Haven and surrounding environs from 1860-1930s. Included are aerial views, scenes of the New Haven Green, photographs of streets, and various individual residences. Of particular interest are the snapshots of houses used for tax purposes, or as documentation of the structure before demolition.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Forms part of Yale Record Group 48-A (YRG 48-A), Yale pictorial records and collections.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Buildings, Grounds and Landmarks in New Haven Photographs (RU 685). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in three series and subsequent accessions. I. Photographs. II. Oversize. III. Folio.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The materials consist of maps, photographs, engravings, drawings, slides, and lithographs of New Haven, Connecticut scenes, residences, buildings, and landmarks. The bulk of The materials consist of photographs of New Haven and surrounding environs from 1860-1930s. Included are aerial views, scenes of the New Haven Green, photographs of streets, and various individual residences. Of particular interest are the snapshots of houses used for tax purposes, or as documentation of the structure before demolition.
